p: As presented in Figure 1B, several significant peaks occurred in the gas chromatogram of leaf essential oil after the heat treatment at 100 °C for 30 min. The content of the main constitute, linalool, was reduced from 93.30% to 64.01% ( Table 1). New constituents were observed for β-myrcene (5.56%), α-phellandrene (0.91%), α-terpinene (1.49%), cis-ocimene (4.70%), γ-terpinene, and terpinolene (2.53%) in the thermally degraded leaf essential oil. Major variations were found for the increasing contents of limonene and trans-ocimene, which were 0.61% and 0.32% in the raw leaf essential oil and obviously increased to 7.77% and 7.94% in the thermally degraded specimen.
